description: Demolition of 13 no. existing garages and erection of 4no. dwellings with 4no. parking spaces, cycle storage and associated landscaping/communal amenity space
decision_conditions: The proposed development would not ensure an acceptable standard of amenity for future occupants, by reason of poor outlook, insufficient internal light levels on lower ground floor levels, and an insufficient provision of private outdoor amenity space, thereby conflicting with Paragraph 127 of the National Planning Policy Framework (2019) Policy 7.6 of the London Plan (2016), Policy DM10 of the Local Development Framework Core Strategy (2012) and Policy Guidance 13 of the Council's Residential Design Supplementary Planning Document (2013).

By virtue of their size, scale, and plot size, the proposed dwellings would appear cramped and inharmonious in relation to the nature of the form of the wider development on site and the prevailing pattern of development within the area. As a result, the proposed development would harm the character and appearance of the surrounding area. This would be contrary to the National Planning Policy Framework (2019),  Policies 7.4 and 7.8 of the London Plan (2016), Policies CS8, DM10 and DM11 of the Council's Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design Supplementary Planning Document (2013).

Due to the limited separation distance, the kitchen/dining room window serving Plot 4 would result in a loss of privacy for the ground floor flat at No.82 to 88 Charter Court. The proposal would therefore conflict with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy (2012) and Policy Guidance 16 of the Residential Design Supplementary Planning Document (2013).

The proposed loss of 13 garages would have an unacceptable adverse impact upon existing car parking provision for the residents of Charter Court resulting in adverse impacts upon traffic congestion, on-street car parking pressure on surrounding roads and vehicular and pedestrian safety in the area. Furthermore, it has not been demonstrated that the Council's refuse vehicles and emergency service vehicles can access and service the proposed dwellings. The proposal would therefore conflict the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), Policy 6.13 of the London Plan (2016), Policies DM9 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy (2012) and Policy  D11 of the Draft New London Plan (2018).

---Officer Report---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021- The South London Waste Plan 2012 - The LDF Core Strategy 2012- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008

---Officer Report---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021- The South London Waste Plan 2012 - The LDF Core Strategy 2012- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008

Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal---End of Officer Report---

The site comprises a semi detached dwelling. It is not located in a Conservation Area or subject to any Article 4 Direction.The application seeks planning permission for the erection of a single-storey rear extension with associated changes to fenestration.The application follows an earlier planning permission (21/02848/HOU) for the same development but with a slightly different roof profile for some of the rear extension. In particular, a small portion of the approved pitched roof would change from a pitched roof to a flat roof.5 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposal. No representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey ground floor extension would replace an existing structure and extend slightly beyond its footprint to the rear of the existing dwelling, with some changes to fenestration to the front and rear. The extension would be of an appropriate height and depth, with an appropriate roof form and external materials to match the host dwelling.Having regard to the above officers consider the development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the surrounding area.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: There is an existing structure located on the boundary shared with No.13 Elgar Avenue and the proposed development would not increase its scale or depth as it relates to, or is visible from this property. To No.9 Elgar Avenue, the proposed extension would be setback from the boundary and compliance with the daylight/sunlight guidance in the Residential Design SPD has been demonstrated.  Officers therefore consider the impacts on amenities would not be unduly compromised.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Please submit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250 with the application site outlined in red and adjoining land owned by applicant in blue, showing at least two road frontages and a North point. We cannot accept copies of plans (such as your title deeds) that were created for other purposes and submission of such plans willmake your application invalid.

The submitted proposed block plan is labelled as existing and does not show the proposed roof plan.Note: Please provide a copy of proposed block plan drawn at an identified standard metric scale (such as 1:200 or 1:500) showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site.  The block plan must show the direction of North and should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.
For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Erection of part hip to gable roof extension with rear dormer and installtion of 3 nos front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion.'
